Expectation1: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation1: A neighboring family has been affected by a house fire and requires immediate assistance with food and clothing.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Late-afternoon errands leave just a couple of hours before the polls close.
Story: I was folding donated clothes in the convent’s storeroom when Sister Agnes rushed in, her face pale. “The Ramirez family’s house caught fire. They have nothing left.” My heart clenched. As a nun, I knew my place was with them, offering food, comfort, and hope. I gathered supplies, ready to go, but as I glanced at the clock, a cold realization struck me—the polls would close in just two hours. Today was election day, and as a citizen, I had a duty to vote, to help shape the future of our community. The polling station was across town, and the errands I’d run earlier had already eaten into my time. I felt torn, the weight of my habit heavy on my shoulders, the voter registration card in my pocket a silent reminder. The expectation to serve those in immediate need pressed against the civic responsibility to participate in democracy. My hands trembled as I packed the last loaf of bread, my mind racing, heart aching, caught between two worlds that both demanded all of me.
